review:
Skyrim was pretty great game, not my favorite of the Elder Scrolls series (that would be Morrowind), but still fun.  It wasn't able to hold my attention for too long, however. Something about the game, the menus, the items, the combat, the world, something didn't feel right. Something was missing. After playing 50+ hours of the xbox 360 version and constantly seeing all the cool things players could do on the pc I finally decided to upgrade my poor old desktop pc to a monster gaming rig.

review:
What really made this game great was mods.  After nearly 4 years and an expansive mod community, Skyrim was really great in the terms of value you saw added to this game, and it's really what kept this game relevant this long.  While I understand and agree that some modders may want to cash in on their work, the current implementation of this is poorly done.
The fact that it's been so poorly curated (we're already seeing junk mods for $99.99 being added) is fracturing the community.  Modders are seeing their work ripped off and sold without their knowledge, and some mods require other mods to work. review:
A few years back a good game was launched named Skyrim. The game felt kind of empty with many limits, shortcomings and a short storyline but was still good. A few modders started to share their first creations and as the community grew, more and more mods and sub-communities saw the day. The work to improve and expand the game was well on its way. The community created tools and resources that other modders used. Ideas was discussed and fantastic mods was created. Today more than 40000 mods is hosted on nexus and the workshop have more than 25000 mods. Countless numbers of videos, reviews, feedbacks and play testing have been produced. The game have expanded and improved in all aspects and the selection of mods,improvements and information is tremendous.
The community surrounding Skyrim have become very large and the popularity of the game followed that growth. And much of this was built on the idea that everyone was free to use the mods and tools that was created by the community. All that changed when Bethesda made it possible to charge money for mods. This change in policy is moving Bethesda in a direction that is undermining the foundation for the popularity and interested around their games. This change in policy will split up the community, create conflicts and reduce number of new mods created. Many will feel betrayed and treated unfairly and those that made the resource and tools that made some of the best mods possible will never be paid.
I'm not against that modders get paid for their work, I'm against the way it was introduced, that they introduced it in a well established community and the way it work on steam. And in return they only give 25% to the modders, its easy to see that this was not act of being kind to the community.

review:
I have almost 200 hours in this game. You know why? Because mods that's why. The freedom to mix and match any mods on a whim. Being able to look up an issue you have, like maybe you find it annoying that you can't dual cast two different spells, and searching for a mod that does just that, downloading, and installing it in a matter of minutes and having a greater gaming experience as a rusult is the reason I've spent an entire week of my life in this game.
But no more. Now all of those mods are stuck behind a paywall. Now to play this game as I used to enjoy I would have to pay at least 100 bucks to get everything I had installed. Now it's just Vanilla Skyrim. A game I played for 10 hours and dropped it on Xbox. Now as far as Valve is conserned, there is one less advantage to PC gaming and that is truly sad. We pride ourselves in the fact that we play games however we want, but now instead of asking ourselves "how would I like to play this game" we'll have to ask "How much am I willing to pay to play this game the way I want?" And that does nothing to help Valve or PC gaming in general.
I am forced to review this game as it were Vanilla now. Because I cannot in good conscience say "this game is great as long as you're willing to put 50 bucks into it!" Which it is. But without mods this game is as wide as the ocean, but deep as a puddle. You'll do the main quest and feel like you had no effect on the world around. People will treat you as a random traveler no matter how many dragon souls you absorb.
If Valve ever get their heads on straight and withdraws this program I would gladly revise this review to reflect what an amazing experience this 5 dollar game could bring, but I sadly can't do that now.

review:
Skyrim is a fantastic game, well worth Steam's full price.
That being said, however, I would not advise anyone to buy this game. Recently, Valve decided to implement a broken system in which users can charge for their mods on the workshop. This has led to extensive copyright infringement, the stifling of creativity, loss of quality control, and greed. Overall, it has divided the once thriving and friendly modding community in two, and I would advise anyone to not give Valve your money for this game until they undo the broken system they've put in and replace it with a donation button.
Valve has done this, they claim, so "players can give back to modders for their work", however the fact that only 25% of the profits goes to modders reveals the true nature of Valve's intent; a money ploy for themselves and Bethesda, in which they recieve 75% of the profits for something they had no involvement in. Furthermore, many steam users posting their thoughts on the forums have been suspended for a week or more from steam, their comments taken down.
Skyrim is a great game, made even greater by the mods that the generous community has put out for years. It's really too bad it had to come to this...
This review will be taken down once Valve announces that paid modding will be no more.
